Posts.Content:
Dear Sunny -
If I were you, I'd definitely have the surgical biopsy! Would you rather have peace of mind or wondering, especially being at high risk like you are. Finding BC in the early stages is so critical and treatable!
I had a surgical biopsy and it was a very simple process. It was outpatient surgery. That saved my life possibly. It's what detected my Breast Cancer!
Of COURSE, it all sounds so scary and you wonder why you have to go through it. I truly thought mine was going to end up just being a big inconvenience. 
I had my appt/consult with surgeon on a Thurs (I believe) and was scheduled for surgery the following Tues. They don't like you to wait and not because of emergency but because of anxiety I think. "Get it over with" was a good mentality to have. 
Good Luck to you. Please keep us updated!
Posts.Title: percentage of malignancy in clustered microcalcifications in one breast only

Posts.Content:
Betsy, I am so sorry that I am just now getting back to you! Wondering how your biopsy went or if you posted it somewhere else?
To answer your questions - 
I had immediate resconstruction of silicone implants. I did not have the tissue expanders. 
I went to one of the top oncologists in our area and found that I do not need to take Tamoxefen nor do I need chemo or radiation. Some do depending on what type of cancer, whether it has spread to lymph nodes etc.
No mammograms and that's why I chose the bi-lateral. Otherwise I would have been in there every 6 months checking the other one. My first 6 month visit is coming up soon. My surgeon said either he or someone (this will be my gynocologist) needs to do a good physical exam, feeling into collar bone and chest area.
They don't like to leave those abnormal cells in there regardless of what stage they're in now. My radiologist explained that there is A, B and C. -
A is abnormal, B is benign and C is cancerous. For everything but B, they like to do something.
Of course, everyone has their own and sometimes very different opinion. :)
Thinking of you!
Posts.Title: percentage of malignancy in clustered microcalcifications in one breast only

Posts.Content:
I had a lump and when looking at that, they found a few different areas of microcalcifications. 
I was shocked when they said it was cancer. To give a percentage I think would be difficult. I looked at it as only "x" percentage are cancerous, but for me in my mind I obviously had a 50/50 chance of hearing the news. 
I quickly had it taken care of - within two weeks I had a double mastectomy w/immediate reconstruction. I am doing well!! 
They are not tumors, but rather a cluster of cells. Hopefully you're going in for a biopsy? Get it over with. I always say it's better to know what you're dealing with.
I don't think regular mammograms 'help' microcalfications. They need to be looked at. They are different from the very common calcifications that many many women have in their breasts.
Please keep us posted! Good Luck and stay strong. :)
Posts.Title: percentage of malignancy in clustered microcalcifications in one breast only

Posts.Content:
I had the same kind of biopsy done months ago - mine was right on top of my breast though. I didn't have the same symptoms. If it's something you're concerned about
, I'd make a quick call to the office. Although probably nothing, I'm sure the nurses are used to answering all sorts of questions. The nurses at my surgeons office were exceptional!
If you decide not to call, if it were me, I'd probably hold off on the yoga until you go back to see Dr. I'd hate to aggravate a situation if there were one. 
Hoping everything turns out great for you!
Posts.Title: excision biopsy yesterday

Posts.Content:
For me to say "relax a little and try not to panic" probably doesn't do much good, but please try to hang in there until you get into your follow up appt. A "mass" can mean lots of things, so the ultrasound will really help them figure out what it is. If you need a biopsy, even if it were to be a surgical excision, you'll get through it! 
I do know that Dr.'s don't delay on any sort of abnormal things found in the breast. When I found a lump, they wanted me in the next day and THAT scared me. BUT, that's what they do. 
There are several distinctions they look for in an ultrasound/sonogram. I wish I could remember them all (your radiologist will be able to tell you), one is if sound waves can penetrate the mass/lump. 
Turned out my lump was benign, unfortunately at the same time they found a few different areas of microcalcifications (which turned out to be cancerous). So for me, my lump was my friend cause it got me the attention I needed. 
Amazing how we DO get through these things. Not knowing is much much harder than knowing what you're dealing with. We as women, are pretty strong! 
Please post after your follow up and let us know how things went.
You'll be in my thoughts and prayers!
Jacey
Posts.Title: Lab called to come for follow-up

Posts.Content:
I ended up having a few different areas of microcalcifications. My biopsy came back as cancer. I opted for a mastectomy. They will want to get all of the microcalifications out. One, two or three didn't matter to me as I was having everything removed.
I had a double mastectomy. Im glad I did because they did find some 'abnormal' cells in my other breast. I just didn't want to be looking over my shoulder for years to come that's why I chose to have a bilateral. I'm very happy with the results and am happy to have that 'crap' out of my breasts!
Good Luck to you. Keep the faith!
Posts.Title: needle core biopsy

Posts.Content:
I don't know if I can put links on here or not, so if you go to hopkinsmedicine dot org, they have a whole page the pros/cons of each reconstructive option. Might be helpful to you.
I just had the regular old bilateral with implants so Im of no help personally. Sorry. 
PS I too had DCIS but because of the areas etc. had to have the whole breast removed. After they took the other breast, they biopsed that one and found abnormal cells as well.
I'm very pleased with my results.
Good Luck in your decision. I know that none of this is easy, but you WILL get through it and be on the other side before you know it!
Posts.Title: diep vs muscle sparing tram

Posts.Content:
I think it's perfectly normal to be a bit panicked. I remember when I found my lump. I could see it if I held my shoulders back.
Call your Dr. right away - not because it's anything bad necessarily, but because they will get you in within a day or two. They didn't want me to wait at all. One way or another you'll find out what is going on and let me tell you, THAT is worth it's weight in gold. Knowledge is power.
I had to wait over a holiday weekend to get in with radiologist. I almost had the video camera out with messages for my kids. I totally understand your fear. 
It is true that most lumps are benign. That and your age are on your side. However, get in so you feel better.
Good Luck and keep us posted!
Posts.Title: Small breast lump. Please help!

Posts.Content:
I know it sounds scary, but I'd be happy that they are being proactive and making sure nothing is there. Depending on what kind of tumor it is - is it a "tumor"? cyst? etc. they may still want to get it out. I had a lump, that they were going to let stay there as it wasn't cancerous. However I ended up having breast cancer outside of that particular lump I later found out. 
Hang in there and hopefully it will be good news!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Biopsy

Posts.Content:
Everything seems scary when you hear any words like 'mass', cancer, tumor, biopsy etc. BUT it is true that most are benign.
I had a lump that I was really worried about
. It turned out to be benign. 
Remember, they have to, and you want them to be proactive and check everything out. 
As mentioned, IF something was truly wrong, you'll get it taken care of and start your life! 
Try to hang in there and come back and tell us how it went!
Jacey
Posts.Title: 27 and Going for a Biopsy

Posts.Content:
I'm so sorry that you're going through all of this!!
I had malignant microcals and had a bilateral mastectomy last Oct. I had them take both partly because of what you're going through. I just didnt' want to worry about
 it for the rest of my life. 
I pray that everything will be fine for you. Of course it will be 'fine', but I hope that your microcals are benign. YOU are obviously a strong woman and will make it through whatever lies ahead.
Thinking of you.
Jacey
Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
I had a mastectomy about
 6 months ago. It all happened very quickly. I was referred to a general surgeon. He did the excisional biopsy as the core needle biopsy wasn't successful. The surgical part can be done by any good surgeon. The oncologist part will come in afterwards once they see what is really going on. After my mastectomy I met with an oncologist. I of course wasn't sure of the process so I inquired and was told that the onc. doesn't necessarily need to get involved until after the surgery. I'm sure all cases are different though. 
My surgeon had a reconstructive surgeon that he teamed up with - he did so on a regular basis. I had a consult with him and was very pleased. He looked at his work like he was an artist which I appreciated. I had reconstruction at the same time.
Posts.Title: needle core biopsy

Posts.Content:
Take that recovery time as a reason to relax! They say no lifting more than 10 lbs for a few weeks I think. The first few days you won't feel like doing much. You'll probably have drains.
Sleep, rest, watch TV, be waited on and pampered if you have someone to help you! I felt unexpectedly much better than I thought I would. For me, the fatigue was way worse than the pain. 
I did find holding my arms up even parallel to the floor was tiring. So holding a steering wheel up on top was hard for me for a while, as well as lifting my arms above my head (washing hair) for 2 weeks or so.
Everyone is a little different.
Good Luck to you!
Posts.Title: restrictions????

Posts.Content:
Hi - 
No I never had blood from my nipples, but my core needle biopsies weren't able to be done. They tried for almost an hour to get to the right place but couldn't. 
I had very little breast tissue. That's a big part of why I chose not to have a lumpectomy w/rad. My surgeon didnt think I'd have a good end result cosmetically.
I'm glad you're going in tomorrow. Hang in there! Please keep us posted!
Will be thinking of you tomorrow.
Jacey
Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
Dr.s don't like to leave anything 'suspicious' or abnormal in the breast, so I'm not surprised they want a surgical biopsy. Like Bev said, it's not bad to go through. I was under general for the first time and I think that scared me more than anything. 
They send results down to pathology right then to make sure they got whole area before they close you up. (At least that's how my surgeon explained it to me beforehand) As far as WHEN you'll get results, that is something to ask. I didn't get a call back right away and when I called for them on a Thurs., was told my Dr. was gone for the weekend. Of course, that would be good news for me right? My case NO, but like Bev said 80% of biopsied tissue is benign. 
It's still scary to think of going through it all, but even when I found out I had BC and would need a mastectomy, knowing what I was dealing with was MUCH better than not. 
Please post an update for us. We'll all be thinking of you I know. TRY to relax a little, pamper yourself and watch some comedy shows/movies. 
Jacey
Posts.Title: Breast Biopsy
